data.protoText: Prepare the bacterial culture
adjust the bacterial population to 106 - 107 cfu/ml

incubate the bacteria under test at
106 cfu/ml with 60 μg puri�ed HMC plus 100 nmol 4-methylcatechol \(4ME) in 100 μl PBS at 37 °C for 1 h.
enumerate the remnant bacterial population in the reaction mixture by plating 100 μl of serially diluted samples on nutrient agar plates
incubate the plate at 37 °C overnight
Perform the colony count and calculate the bacterial cfu/ml
add 10 nmol of phenylthiourea \(PTU) to the reactions in order to evaluate the impact of PO activity
also set up controls by incubating bacteria with HMC/PPO or 4ME or PTU separately, or in combinations.
For real-time imaging of the bacterial clearance elicited by HMC/PPO
mix each bacterial strain at 107 cfu/ml with 60 μg HMC/PPO and 100 nmol 4ME in 100 μl PBS
apply one μl of the mixture to �uorescence microscopy
examine it at magni�cation of 63 x 1.6, with time-elapse method
capture images at intervals of 30 s for 1 h, and make a movie.
For the end-point measurement of metHb
incubate the bacteria under test at 106 cfu/ml with 36 μg metHb and 1.6 μmol H2O2 in 200 μl PBS at 37 °C for 1 h
enumerate the remnant bacterial population in the reaction mixture by plating 100 μl of serially diluted samples on nutrient agar plates and incubating at 37 °C overnight
Perform the colony count and calculate the bacterial cfu/ml
to further prove that the antibacterial activity was indeed attributable to ROS, apply 2 μmol GSH to the incubation mixture to quench the superoxide ions.
set up controls by incubating bacteria with metHb, H2O2 or GSH separately or in combinations.
For the end-point measurement of HMC/PPO
